articles.headline: Apple Acknowledges Flaw in iPhone Signal Meter
articles.snippet: In response to complaints, Apple said it would fix the way the signal strength is displayed on the new iPhone.
articles.abstract: In response to complaints, Apple said it would fix the way the signal strength is displayed on the new iPhone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple customers love to complain about the reception on their iPhones. And the problem may be worse than it looks.

articles.headline: Looks and Sounds Like a Bank, but Isn’t, Quite
articles.snippet: Some companies, while offering attractive rewards and interest rates on savings, play up the fact that they aren’t banks. Well, not exactly anyway.
articles.abstract: Some companies, while offering attractive rewards and interest rates on savings, play up the fact that they aren’t banks. Well, not exactly anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re setting out to reinvent basic savings and checking accounts, one way to get attention is to create a service that’s truly different.

articles.headline: More Blacks See Hope in Economy
articles.snippet: Even though they are more likely than whites to be unemployed, black Americans are more likely to see light at the end of the tunnel.
articles.abstract: Even though they are more likely than whites to be unemployed, black Americans are more likely to see light at the end of the tunnel.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Great Recession hit American blacks harder than it did whites. Blacks were more likely to lose their jobs, and those who kept them were more likely to have their pay or hours reduced. Black homeowners are also far more likely than whites to own homes that are no longer worth what they owe on the mortgage.

articles.headline: Hearings That Aren’t Just Theater
articles.snippet: Members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission wield a kind of understated pointedness that is more effective than a dozen angry diatribes.
articles.abstract: Members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission wield a kind of understated pointedness that is more effective than a dozen angry diatribes.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We’ve gotten our sea legs,” said Phil Angelides.

articles.headline: G.M. Is Said to Consider Filing Soon for Offering
articles.snippet: The company, which emerged from bankruptcy last July, is seeking to repay billions of dollars in government loans.
articles.abstract: The company, which emerged from bankruptcy last July, is seeking to repay billions of dollars in government loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors is aiming to file an initial public offering of stock in mid-August, taking its biggest step yet toward repaying the federal government, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Illinois Stops Paying Its Bills, but Can’t Stop Digging Hole
articles.snippet: Illinois’s borrow-and-spend mentality has led it to the brink, but still lawmakers opt not to cut budgets or raise taxes.
articles.abstract: Illinois’s borrow-and-spend mentality has led it to the brink, but still lawmakers opt not to cut budgets or raise taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Even by the standards of this deficit-ridden state, Illinois’s comptroller, Daniel W. Hynes, faces an ugly balance sheet. Precisely how ugly becomes clear when he beckons you into his office to examine his daily briefing memo.

articles.headline: You Say God Is Dead? There’s an App for That
articles.snippet: A new wave of iPhone applications is giving both sides quick points to use in the debate over the existence of God.
articles.abstract: A new wave of iPhone applications is giving both sides quick points to use in the debate over the existence of God.
articles.lead_paragraph: An explosion of smart-phone software has placed an arsenal of trivia at the fingertips of every corner-bar debater, with talking points on sports, politics and how to kill a zombie. Now it is taking on the least trivial topic of all: God.

articles.headline: War in Iraq Defies U.S. Timetable for End of Combat
articles.snippet: Even after a reduction in troop numbers, American forces will still hunt terrorists after the August deadline that President Obama set for the end of the combat mission in Iraq.
articles.abstract: Even after a reduction in troop numbers, American forces will still hunt terrorists after the August deadline that President Obama set for the end of the combat mission in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEAR TULUL AL-BAQ, Iraq  President Obama has set an August deadline for the end of the combat mission in Iraq. Here at this makeshift desert camp in the insurgent badlands of northern Iraq, a mission is under way that is not going to stop then: American soldiers hunting terrorists and covertly watching an Iraqi checkpoint staffed by police officers whom the soldiers say they do not trust.

articles.headline: High-Rise, or House With Yard?
articles.snippet: An assessment meant to mirror a decision a family of four in the New York metropolitan area might face found that suburban living cost 18 percent more than urban living.
articles.abstract: An assessment meant to mirror a decision a family of four in the New York metropolitan area might face found that suburban living cost 18 percent more than urban living.
articles.lead_paragraph: The question starts to hang in the air sometime after the children arrive, and the apartment in the city begins to feel a little tight: Should we consider moving to a house in the suburbs?

articles.headline: In a Refuge Haunted by Katrina, BP Swirls In
articles.snippet: A former  school that housed volunteers working to restore St. Bernard Parish after Hurricane Katrina will house workers helping to clean up the oil spill.
articles.abstract: A former  school that housed volunteers working to restore St. Bernard Parish after Hurricane Katrina will house workers helping to clean up the oil spill.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARABI, La.

articles.headline: They Did Their Homework (800 Years of It)
articles.snippet: Many economists build careers on only a few decades’ worth of data. Kenneth Rogoff and Carmen Reinhart researched eight centuries of financial crises for “This Time Is Different.”
articles.abstract: Many economists build careers on only a few decades’ worth of data. Kenneth Rogoff and Carmen Reinhart researched eight centuries of financial crises for “This Time Is Different.”
articles.lead_paragraph: THE advertisement warns of speculative financial bubbles. It mocks a group of gullible Frenchmen seduced into a silly, 18th-century investment scheme, noting that the modern shareholder, armed with superior information, can avoid the pitfalls of the past. “How different the position of the investor today!” the ad enthuses.

articles.headline: Bidder Beware
articles.snippet: When News Corporation bought the parent of MySpace, a question of whether Viacom was ignored as a suitor.
articles.abstract: When News Corporation bought the parent of MySpace, a question of whether Viacom was ignored as a suitor.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S a shareholder’s worst nightmare. A company is in play, with two potential acquirers circling it, but the board of directors and others running the enterprise  who are supposed to snare top dollar for shareholders  favor bidders who are dangling the biggest rewards for directors and senior executives.

articles.headline: Where BP’s Money Is Landing
articles.snippet: BP has paid out about $144 million so far, and the bill is expected to grow exponentially.
articles.abstract: BP has paid out about $144 million so far, and the bill is expected to grow exponentially.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS the Gulf of Mexico continues to fill with oil this summer, condos and restaurants will sit empty, fishing boats will stay docked, and beaches  even those without a single tar ball  will attract fewer tourists.

articles.headline: Nudge on Arms Further Divides the U.S. and Israel
articles.snippet: The United States has urged Israel to sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, yielding to demands by Arab nations.
articles.abstract: The United States has urged Israel to sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, yielding to demands by Arab nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was only one paragraph buried deep in the most plain-vanilla kind of diplomatic document, 40 pages of dry language committing 189 nations to a world free of nuclear weapons. But it has become the latest source of friction between Israel and the United States in a relationship that has lurched from crisis to crisis over the last few months.

articles.headline: Russian Mayor Irks Security Agency, and Suffers
articles.snippet: A mayor who filed a lawsuit over a resort owned by Russia’s security service was jailed and prosecuted.
articles.abstract: A mayor who filed a lawsuit over a resort owned by Russia’s security service was jailed and prosecuted.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISTVYANKA, Russia — On the edge of this Siberian village is a resort with a veiled guest list and armed guards at the front gate. When local officials have expressed unease about what goes on inside, the reply has always been the same: do not interfere.

articles.headline: As Oil Industry Fights a Tax, It Reaps Subsidies
articles.snippet: Oil production is among the most heavily subsidized businesses, with tax breaks available at virtually every stage of the exploration and extraction process.
articles.abstract: Oil production is among the most heavily subsidized businesses, with tax breaks available at virtually every stage of the exploration and extraction process.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Deepwater Horizon drilling platform set off the worst oil spill at sea in American history, it was flying the flag of the Marshall Islands. Registering there allowed the rig’s owner to significantly reduce its American taxes.

articles.headline: Rougher Road for Democrats With Obama Off Ticket
articles.snippet: In a midterm election year, Democrats defending House districts they captured from Republicans are trying to recreate the Obama campaign machinery.
articles.abstract: In a midterm election year, Democrats defending House districts they captured from Republicans are trying to recreate the Obama campaign machinery.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — The congressman was dripping with sweat, and his face was as red as a tomato as he moved through a crowded park here, passing out dozens of plastic cups bearing his name.

articles.headline: Nickelodeon Tries Again to Move to the Big Screen
articles.snippet: Film projects born out of the children’s television empire are lined up like parade floats at Paramount Pictures.
articles.abstract: Film projects born out of the children’s television empire are lined up like parade floats at Paramount Pictures.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Nickelodeon brand is finally getting the red-carpet treatment from Paramount Pictures.

articles.headline: China Fears Consumer Impact on Global Warming
articles.snippet: Experts worry that as China’s 1.3 billion people clamor for more cars and creature comforts, international efforts to limit global warming could be doomed.
articles.abstract: Experts worry that as China’s 1.3 billion people clamor for more cars and creature comforts, international efforts to limit global warming could be doomed.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — Premier Wen Jiabao has promised to use an “iron hand” this summer to make his nation more energy efficient. The central government has ordered cities to close inefficient factories by September, like the vast Guangzhou Steel mill here, where most of the 6,000 workers will be laid off or pushed into early retirement.

articles.headline: Companies Find Ways to Bypass Ban on Earmarks
articles.snippet: There is a ban on earmarks to profit-making companies, but dozens of requests have been made anyway.
articles.abstract: There is a ban on earmarks to profit-making companies, but dozens of requests have been made anyway.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Pakistan Army Finds Taliban Tough to Root Out
articles.snippet: Months after declaring victory in South Waziristan and the Swat Valley, the army has been forced to reopen campaigns after militants seeped back in.
articles.abstract: Months after declaring victory in South Waziristan and the Swat Valley, the army has been forced to reopen campaigns after militants seeped back in.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAZMAK, Pakistan  On an operating table at a makeshift trauma center at this military base in North Waziristan, a Pakistani soldier lay anesthetized, blood-soaked bandages applied in the field just an hour earlier a testament to a near-fatal wound.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Retailers Devise Novel Ways to Revive Sales
articles.snippet: Tired of waiting for spending to rebound, retailers are offering unconventional promotions to attract visitors.
articles.abstract: Tired of waiting for spending to rebound, retailers are offering unconventional promotions to attract visitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tired of waiting for spending to rebound on its own, retailers are taking matters into their own hands. Stores like Sam’s Club, Target, Toys “R” Us, Staples and Office Depot are offering unconventional promotions meant not only to attract visitors to stores, but also to get them feeling profligate.

articles.headline: Old Movie Houses Find Audience in the Plains
articles.snippet: A grass-roots movement is trying to keep Main Street movie houses, with their jewel-like marquees, at the center of community life.
articles.abstract: A grass-roots movement is trying to keep Main Street movie houses, with their jewel-like marquees, at the center of community life.
articles.lead_paragraph: LANGDON, N. D.  Every Friday through Monday night, from her perch behind the Skittles and the M&M’s, Amy Freier awaits the faithful at the historic Roxy Theater. There is Dale Klein, the school bus driver (large Diet Pepsi with a refill). And there is Jeannette Schefter, the social worker (large plain popcorn, medium Diet).

articles.headline: Microsoft Calling. Anyone There?
articles.snippet: Its recent cancellation of the Kin smartphone adds to a long list of product misfires — from watches to music players — that have plagued Microsoft’s consumer division.
articles.abstract: Its recent cancellation of the Kin smartphone adds to a long list of product misfires — from watches to music players — that have plagued Microsoft’s consumer division.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s engineers and executives spent two years creating a new line of smartphones with playful names that sounded like creatures straight out of “The Cat in the Hat”  Kin One and Kin Two. Stylish designs, an emphasis on flashy social-networking features and an all-out marketing blitz were meant to prove that Microsoft could build the right product at the right time for the finickiest customers  gossiping youngsters with gadget skills.

articles.headline: A Political Clash Over Deficits Stalls Legislation to Address Jobs
articles.snippet: Democrats hope voters will punish Republicans in the midterm elections for blocking extended unemployment benefits; Republicans believe the public is more concerned about deficits.
articles.abstract: Democrats hope voters will punish Republicans in the midterm elections for blocking extended unemployment benefits; Republicans believe the public is more concerned about deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress headed for a recess over the weekend having failed to agree on legislation to address the nation’s fragile employment picture, with both parties placing starkly different bets on the political consequences of their positions.

articles.headline: Outspoken Is Great, Till It’s Not
articles.snippet: Dave Weigel, the Washington Post political blogger who resigned over comments about conservatives, was just what the paper wanted.
articles.abstract: Dave Weigel, the Washington Post political blogger who resigned over comments about conservatives, was just what the paper wanted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wanted: Political blogger covering the conservative movement. Must be provocative and write with a strong point of view although not in a way that would reveal bias or offend any of your potential subjects. Social media a plus until it’s not. Must be completely transparent, unless that proves embarrassing to the newspaper. Send sanitized résumé, innocuous clips and nonpartisan references to The Washington Post.

articles.headline: At Yahoo, Using Searches to Steer News Coverage
articles.snippet: The editors of The Upshot will use search data to create news articles that — if the process works as intended — will draw in more readers.
articles.abstract: The editors of The Upshot will use search data to create news articles that — if the process works as intended — will draw in more readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the era of the algorithm as editor.
